captions.text:
What would your friends say, on a hot summers
day, if you could open up a bottle of water

and pour out an instant snow cone? In this
project we're exploring some tips, some tricks,

and everything else you'll need to know, to
master the art of making instant ice.

In a previous video, we turned water like
this, directly to ice in just an instant.

For this project you'll just need some purified
water, and the easiest place to find that

is in a water bottle. Go ahead and throw about
6 bottles in the freezer, because the more

bottles you start with, the better chances
you're gonna have for success. The temperature

dial in my freezer was set to 5 of 7, and
that settled to a temperature of -24ºC or

around -11ºF. Now, these bottles have been
sitting at room temperature overnight, and

in my experience this trick works best if
they're evenly spaced, and placed on their

sides. The minute the door closes, make a
note of the time. After an hour and a half,

check your bottles to see if any of them have
frozen. If they're all still liquid, then

quickly close the door, but keep checking
on them every 15 minutes. For these particular

bottles, it took 2 hours and 45 minutes for
the first one to freeze. Looking at the bottle,

you can see it's not frozen solid, but you
should see flakes of ice floating around under

the plastic. At this point, stop and take
note of the time. Then subtract 15 minutes,

and now you have a supercooling formula for
your favorite brand of water. In my case,

this trick works from 2-1/2 hours to 2 hours
and 45 minutes. Now if the bottles in the

freezer, haven't frozen yet, take them out
very gently. This water is well below freezing,

but hasn't frozen yet because there aren't
any impurities to get it started. The water

does want to freeze, and that's why something
as simple as a jolt to the side can be enough

to nucleate the ice formation, and just like
magic, you've got instant ice. You'll notice

that bottles this cold will develop a layer
of condensation making it harder to see inside,

so go ahead and wipe that off. This way, when
you hit it, you'll have a much better view

of the crystal formations. Another way to
start your water freezing, is to use a piece

of ice. Put the ice anywhere you want, and
then pour your water overtop. You should see

it freeze instantly, and build quickly into
instant ice sculptures like these. I put an

ice cube on this rock, and you can see the
crystals build every time the water makes

contact with the ice. You could make this
easier by using a whole bowl of ice. Now if

you start pouring your water, and it doesn't
look like it's building pillars very quickly,

it means your water hasn't cooled enough,
and probably needs another 5-10 minutes in

the freezer. This bottle did come out 10 minutes
later, and you can see a dramatic difference

in how quickly it freezes. If you leave your
bottles in the freezer too long, They may

be so sensitive that even wiping the side
of the bottle initiates the freeze. And it

could be complete before you even get the
cap off. If you do get the cap off, pouring

too slowly might result in this effect where
the water doesn't pour out at all. And that's

because it iced up in the bottle neck, and
it's freezing the rest of the way down. If

you're wondering how cold the water actually
is, I was able to measure one bottle at -4.5ºC

/ 24ºF, and there's a good chance they are
actually colder than that. If you try pouring

this supercooled liquid into a glass, you
might notice it looks a little thick and syrupy.

If you get to this point, try touching the
surface gently with an ice cube. Everything

freezes firm enough to hold the ice cube in
place, and makes a nice little platform to

continue building your ice towers. When trying
this approach, it's important that the glass

is extremely clean, because even a microscopic
impurity can trigger the nucleation, and solidify

your experiment prematurely. You could try
using this effect to pour yourself an instant

snow cone. As the water freezes, it actually
releases latent heat in the reaction and warms

the ice into a delicious slush. I tried using
the juice in these freeze pops as a make-shift

snow-cone syrup, and poured it on top to get
3 different flavors. Well, now you know everything

you need to know about making instant ice.
If you want to see colored crystals, try pouring

2 drops of food coloring in the water before
you freeze it. Well, that's it for now. If

you liked this project, perhaps you'll like
some of my others. Check them out at www.thekingofrandom.com

title: Instant Ice - Tips, Tricks, and Things to Watch Out For!
